importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating the timing of the news about Daniel Naroditsky's death.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time span from when Naroditsky won the Under 12 world championship in 2007 to his death in 2025 reflects his long-standing career and influence in chess.

keyTakeAways: Daniel Naroditsky, a chess grandmaster, died at age 29 in October 2025.
He was born in San Mateo County, California, to Jewish immigrant parents from Ukraine and Azerbaijan.
Naroditsky became a grandmaster at age 18 and won the Under 12 world championship at a young age.
He was consistently ranked in the top 200 in traditional chess and top 25 in blitz chess throughout his career.
Naroditsky won the U.S. National Blitz Championship in August 2025.
He was widely known for livestreaming chess matches and providing live commentary on YouTube and Twitch, helping to popularize chess among a broader audience.
Fellow grandmasters, including Hikaru Nakamura and Benjamin Bok, praised his educational approach and friendship.
He studied history at Stanford University and earned a bachelor’s degree in 2019.
After college, he coached junior players in Charlotte, North Carolina, at the Charlotte Chess Center.
The cause of death was not immediately known.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Daniel Naroditsky, a child prodigy and American chess grandmaster, died at age 29 in October 2025. Born in San Mateo County, California, to Jewish immigrants from Ukraine and Azerbaijan, he became a grandmaster at 18 and won the Under 12 world championship in 2007. He studied history at Stanford University before moving to Charlotte, North Carolina, where he coached junior players at the Charlotte Chess Center. Naroditsky gained widespread popularity through live streaming on platforms like YouTube and Twitch, where he provided educational commentary and helped expand chess's reach. He won the U.S. National Blitz Championship in August 2025 and was celebrated by fellow grandmasters for his passion, teaching, and friendship. The cause of death was not immediately known.
title: American chess grandmaster Daniel Naroditsky dies at 29
